an5.75:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five warriors are found in the world.

an5.75:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco yodhājīvo rajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.75:1.3.eng: Firstly, one warrior falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.75:1.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:1.5.eng: This is the first warrior found in the world.

an5.75:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ;
an5.75:2.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust,

an5.75:2.2.pli: api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.75:2.2.eng: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.75:2.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:2.4.eng: This is the second warrior found in the world.

an5.75:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ sahati dhajaggaṃ;
an5.75:3.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,

an5.75:3.2.pli: api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
an5.75:3.2.eng: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

an5.75:3.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:3.4.eng: This is the third warrior found in the world.

an5.75:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ;
an5.75:4.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,

an5.75:4.2.pli: api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati.
an5.75:4.2.eng: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.

an5.75:4.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:4.4.eng: This is the fourth warrior found in the world.

an5.75:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ, sahati sampahāraṃ.
an5.75:5.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck.

an5.75:5.2.pli: So taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an5.75:5.2.eng: He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an5.75:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:5.4.eng: This is the fifth warrior found in the world.

an5.75:5.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an5.75:5.5.eng: These are the five warriors found in the world.

an5.75:6.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:6.1.eng: In the same way, these five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.

an5.75:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:6.3.eng: Firstly, one monk falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:6.4.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:6.7.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā’ti.
an5.75:6.7.eng: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.’

an5.75:6.8.pli: So taṃ sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:6.8.eng: Hearing this, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:6.9.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo rajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ;
an5.75:7.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who falters and founders at the mere sight of a cloud of dust.

an5.75:7.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:7.4.eng: This is the first individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.75:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṃ;
an5.75:8.1.eng: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust,

an5.75:8.2.pli: api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:8.2.eng: but at the mere sight of a banner’s crest he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:8.3.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:8.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho suṇāti:
an5.75:8.5.eng: It’s when a monk doesn’t hear:

an5.75:8.6.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā’ti;
an5.75:8.6.eng: ‘In such and such a village or town there’s a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.’

an5.75:8.7.pli: api ca kho sāmaṃ passati itthiṃ vā kumāriṃ vā abhirūpaṃ dassanīyaṃ pāsādikaṃ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṃ.
an5.75:8.7.eng: But he sees for himself a women or a girl who is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty.

an5.75:8.8.pli: So taṃ disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:8.8.eng: Seeing her, he falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:8.9.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ;
an5.75:9.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust,

an5.75:9.2.pli: api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ;
an5.75:9.2.eng: but he falters and founders at the mere sight of a banner’s crest.

an5.75:9.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:9.5.eng: This is the second individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.75:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ;
an5.75:10.1.eng: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,

an5.75:10.2.pli: api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:10.2.eng: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:10.3.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:10.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ araññagataṃ vā rukkhamūlagataṃ vā suññāgāragataṃ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā ūhasati ullapati ujjagghati uppaṇḍeti.
an5.75:10.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She smiles, chats, laughs, and teases him.

an5.75:10.6.pli: So mātugāmena ūhasiyamāno ullapiyamāno ujjagghiyamāno uppaṇḍiyamāno saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
an5.75:10.6.eng: He falters and founders. He doesn’t stay firm, and fails to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.75:10.7.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.75:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ;
an5.75:11.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest,

an5.75:11.2.pli: api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati, na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ;
an5.75:11.2.eng: but he falters and founders at the mere sound of turmoil.

an5.75:11.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:11.5.eng: This is the third individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.75:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ;
an5.75:12.1.eng: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil,

an5.75:12.2.pli: api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati.
an5.75:12.2.eng: but he’s killed or injured when blows are struck.

an5.75:12.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ araññagataṃ vā rukkhamūlagataṃ vā suññāgāragataṃ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
an5.75:12.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.

an5.75:12.5.pli: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno sikkhaṃ apaccakkhāya dubbalyaṃ anāvikatvā methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevati.
an5.75:12.5.eng: Without resigning the training and declaring his inability to continue, he indulges in sex.

an5.75:13.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ, api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati;
an5.75:13.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, but is killed or injured when blows are struck.

an5.75:13.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:13.4.eng: This is the fourth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.75:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ, sahati sampahāraṃ, so taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an5.75:14.1.eng: Furthermore, one monk can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil, and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an5.75:14.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ araññagataṃ vā rukkhamūlagataṃ vā suññāgāragataṃ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
an5.75:14.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant who has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut is approached by a lady. She sits right by him, lies down, or embraces him.

an5.75:14.4.pli: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno viniveṭhetvā vinimocetvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
an5.75:14.4.eng: But he disentangles and frees himself, and goes wherever he wants.

an5.75:14.5.pli: So vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
an5.75:14.5.eng: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

an5.75:15.1.pli: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
an5.75:15.1.eng: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes mindfulness in his presence.

an5.75:15.2.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti;
an5.75:15.2.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.

an5.75:15.3.pli: byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti;
an5.75:15.3.eng: Giving up ill will and malevolence, he meditates with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.

an5.75:15.4.pli: thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti;
an5.75:15.4.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, he meditates with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

an5.75:15.5.pli: uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti;
an5.75:15.5.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, he meditates without restlessness, his mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

an5.75:15.6.pli: vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
an5.75:15.6.eng: Giving up doubt, he meditates having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

an5.75:15.7.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
an5.75:15.7.eng: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

an5.75:15.8.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption …

an5.75:15.9.eng: second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an5.75:16.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
an5.75:16.1.eng: When his mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

an5.75:16.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti,
an5.75:16.2.eng: He truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an5.75:16.3.pli: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an5.75:16.3.eng: He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

an5.75:16.4.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati,
an5.75:16.4.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an5.75:16.5.eng: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.

an5.75:16.6.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
an5.75:16.6.eng: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

an5.75:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṃ, sahati dhajaggaṃ, sahati ussāraṇaṃ, sahati sampahāraṃ, so taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati;
an5.75:17.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who can prevail over a cloud of dust and a banner’s crest and turmoil and being struck. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an5.75:17.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.75:17.4.eng: This is the fifth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.75:17.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsū”ti.
an5.75:17.5.eng: These five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.”
